text: An unfinished section of tunnel carved through bare earth braced with pit-props and shored with timber. Rubble and wood and construction equipment are scattered around. Dim work-lights are strung along the roof, but barely illuminate the scene. An emergency generator CLATTERS awa somewhere in the b.g. At the junction of a dark side-tunnel, two Organisation T guards -- a SERGEANT and a CORPORAL -- are working furiou HAMMERING huge lengths of timber across the mouth of the tunnel, gradually sealing it off. Their noses and mouths are masked against the dust by gri cotton scarves, but their unease is plain to see. As they continue working, an 0.T. PRIVATE emerges from th gloom of the main tunnel, jogging towards them. He slows a halt as he joins his two comrades, and begins to quickl fill them in.
That’s the last of them. Everybody else is out. The Sergeant glances around at the Private, but doesn’t s working.
Put a face mask on, you idiot! But the young Private seems impatient and cavalier. He ignores the comment and simply wipes the sweat from his n gesturing curiously at the side-tunnel:
Look, when do we find out the big secret? What's the panic? What're we supposed to be afraid of? The other two exchange a glance.

Never you mind! Just give us a hand to finish up. Quick! The Private joins in reluctantly, and they hoist another thick plank into place, holding it in position while the Corporal HAMMERS a nail through one end.  2. A CREAK -- and dust begins to spill from the roof. The Corporal carries on regardless, NAILING the other end. But the Private is still inquisitive.
Nobody out there’s got a clue what’s going on. wWhy’re we doing this?

Because we've been ordered to! Isn't that enough for you? Another plank is lifted into place, and the barricade is nearing completion... then the distant CLATTER of the generator falters. The lights dim -- then brighten again as the generator returns to its previous steady rhythm. The two NCO's FREEZE -- holding their breath -- looking a each other with speechless expectation. The generator SPLUTTERS again -- terminally, this time. They let go of the plank, and it CRASHES to the floor. Scrabbling for their torches, starting to panic. The Priv watching bemused as the other two CURSE under their breat The Generator NOISE is now on a rapid downward curve, slo and dying. The lights are going with it... ... and a solid, shocking blackness drops on them with su SILENCE. Their torches are on but the beams are feeble, struggling penetrate the darkness. The Sergeant can't help himself: SERGEANT (cont'd) Oh, Christ! His voice ECHOES away into the darkness.
The generator’s just out of petrol. What's so --

Shhh! A pause ... then, from the side-tunnel, comes a new noise: A fain SCUFFLING sound.  3. They automatically shine their torches at the barricade their fear tangible now -- affecting even the young Priva whose cocky expression of disdain is rapidly dropping fro his face. The Sergeant’s voice is tight:
It's happening! Just like they said!

What is it? Is someone in there? But the other two are already backing away along the tunn in horrified disbelief. The Private begins to follow after them, his nervousness growing by the second... the SCUFFLING getting LOUDER... PRIVATE (cont’d) For God's sake, what is it? What's in there? But the other two turn and RUN.
And as his composure finally crumbles and he RUNS after t the Private looks BACK over his shoulder one last time -- face now betraying an expression of sheer terror...

Densely packed pine trees in all directions. Snowflakes flutter down silently from a steel-grey sky. A German Army supply lorry crawls along a dirt road which winds through the forest, engine racing and wheels spinni as it slithers through the river of mud churned up by a hundred tanks and vehicles long gone. Accompanying it are a score of infantry, breath pluming i the frosty air. Some trudge alongside the lorry, offering shoulder occasionally to straighten it as it fishtails through the slush. The remainder follow twenty yards behi Each is sagging under the weight of helmet, equipment and sodden greatcoat. Their uniforms mark them as regular army -- but their coa carry the black and silver cuff-bands of an ‘elite’ divis  4. ENGELS, heading up the group of stragglers, reaches into bread-bag and pulls out a half-eaten bar of chocolate. He pops a piece into his mouth, and chomps it wearily. Following in his wake are EBERT, SCHENKE, KREUZMANN, BAUM HEYDRICH, unit medic FRANKE, and C.0., LT. KRUPP. We’1ll to know each of them soon enough. Two or three others mak up the numbers -- but our group of eight are the main pla for now.
They’11 be heading on to Brussels without us, at this rate. Ebert, moving with a lithe, cat-like alertness despite hi tiredness, throws Engels an idle sideways glance.
What’s your hurry?
(a snort, butting in) Well, it’s not to win any medals that’s for sure. Engels ignores Schenke’s comment, and responds to Ebert’s question.
What’s the hurry? Have a guess.
(bored) The women.
God, no! They’re like French women - coarse hair and wide-pored skin. Next guess. Heydrich -- older than the rest, a veteran -- chips in.
Surely not the booze?

(shaking head) Nah! Cat’s piss, all of it. (to them all) Any more? Engels looks around -- but nobody else is interested exce Kreuzmann, who is looking to him eagerly for the answer Engels glances around once more, then sighs in defeat.  ENGELS (cont’d) Only two good things ever came out of Belgium: one’s the road to Germany, and the other... Engels snaps off a chunk of chocolate, and tosses it back Kreuzmann with a wink and a warm smile. Kreuzmann quickly tears off the remaining wrapper with nervy fingers.
Chocolate! Engels cocks his head appreciatively.

Got it. You can say what you like, but they make damned good -- A bullet SMACKS into Engels’ throat, blowing a chunk out his neck as it exits. The distant RIFLE SHOT follows a second behind. Almost simultaneously, a demolition charge EXPLODES under lorry ahead, taking the legs off the accompanying troops. The front end of the vehicle HEAVES into the air and CRAS back down in a smoking ruin. The group SCATTER as a hail of SNIPER FIRE rains down: Heydrich catches a bullet in the leg, and he and Ebert he forward and left off the road; Baumann takes a gully seve yard back, also to the left; Schenke, Kreuzmann, Krupp an Franke dive right. The rest take cover as best they can. Engels, paralysed, drops to his knees in the mud. Hands a his throat stemming the stream of blood. Jaw working to speak, but only producing GURGLES. He’s HIT again, in the shoulder, but still remains upright.

(a scream) Get him out of there! But all attention is focussed forward as the rest of the swing into action in unison, settling behind cover to ret FIRE with well-practised precision. With bullets SPITTING down all around, it’s all they can do to stay put. . while their legless, dying comrades SCREAM in the b.g.
snuggle into cover across the road, Heydrich dragging his injured leg painfully. Shock and confusion showing on their pale faces.
How bad’s the leg? Heydrich simply shakes his head, more concerned about Eng who’s still propped up on his knees in the kill-zone.
We need to give Engels some covering fire - see if someone can get to him.
Angle’s wrong from here. Sniper- fire’s coming from up left somewhere.
What about retreating to that gully back there ...? Someone BURSTS through the bushes suddenly behind them -- their guns are half turned in response before they realis it’s Baumann.
We’ve got to move! They’re coming up from behind. Ebert looks around, alert.
I don’t see any --
I tell you they’re coming. It’s a trap! Heydrich and Ebert cast a concerned glance over at their stricken comrade -- then Ebert makes a hasty decision.

Alright. Let’s find cover forward. They jump to it and move forward through the trees, rifle pointed in readiness, Heydrich limping along as best he c But they’ve barely gone ten yards before a MACHINE GUN op up from somewhere front right, bullets CHOPPING into the trunks all around them -- forcing them back EBERT (cont’d) Shit! ! Baumann and Ebert run for cover -- but Heydrich trips... As bullets KICK into the snow around him, Heydrich SHOUTS help involuntarily...

Slumped in the kill-zone, Engels is on automatic pilot. Despite his appalling injuries his free hand struggles to open the flap on his holster, to get to his P.38. He just manages it when two more bullets CHOP into him, smashing into arm and abdomen. He slumps back on his haunches with a gurgled MOAN -- but miraculously, still stays upright.
huddle deeper behind cover as a sustained FUSILLADE of sh rains down upon them suddenly.

Christ!! Kreuzmann is making no attempt to return fire, simply sta impotently at Engels, who has somehow summoned the streng to shuffle around towards them, vainly trying to inch his to cover. Franke, meanwhile -- his helmet bearing the red cross of field medic -- averts his eyes so as not to look upon the he cannot help. Lieutenant Krupp is looking around for options.
We’re dead if we stay here! (a shout) Heydrich! Baumann!? No reply.

Where are they? The sniper fire abates momentarily. But then something small, ovoid and black sails gracefully out of the trees towards them, SPLASHING heavily into the mud beside Engel SCHENKE (cont’d) (a shout) Grenade! ! Schenke, Krupp and Franke hit the dirt -- but Kreuzmann i frozen in horror, his eyes locked with those of Engels. The grenade EXPLODES with a sharp, shattering blast, taki Engels with it.  And Kreuzmann is caught in the shockwave...

Silence. A forest clearing. It’s later. Darker. Dusk is falling with the snow. A few brief moments of perfect stillness i the picture-postcard scene, far away from the action. Not even the distant thud of gunfire any longer. Then Ebert, Heydrich and Baumann stumble through the tree Ebert scans the forest ahead with exhausted eyes, his rif held ready at his side -- his free arm supporting the accident-prone Heydrich. Heydrich’s leg, by now, is soake with crusted blood. His face is creased with pain, but st he keeps watch left and right, pistol in hand. Baumann brings up the rear. He’s edgy, scanning the trees behind them with rifle aimed. A few more steps, and Ebert pauses to catch his breath. H whispers, just loud enough for Baumann to hear.

Wait a minute. Baumann crouches and waits, still covering the rear. Untangling himself from Heydrich, Ebert creeps forward an takes up position beside a tree several yards away, study the forest ahead through field-glasses. After a moment, he lowers the binoculars triumphantly. EBERT (cont’d) Bunker!

EXT. ANTI-TANK BUNKER ‘FRIEDA’ - DUSK CLOSE -- as the steel-shutter of a narrow observation loo hole SLIDES open suddenly. A glint of eyes in the darknes beyond. Three metres to the left, in a second loophole sunk into camouflaged concrete face of the bunker, the twin barrels a combined anti-tank cannon/machine gun swivel into actio taking aim. There is the heavy metallic CLICK-CLACK of a gun being cocked. A muffled voice SHOUTS from inside
Stay where you are! and Ebert’s distant voice replies from off-screen:

Don’t shoot! Comrade! WIDER -- down a shallow snow-covered slope, on a frozen d road which dog-legs through rows of concrete tank-traps, three approaching soldiers stop dead in their tracks. Ebert waves his rifle wearily, a dirty white handkerchief tied to the barrel. He calls again, cautious: EBERT (cont’d) We’re coming in. Alright? No reply from the bunker. Ebert sets off again anyway, half-dragging Heydrich up th slope. Baumann follows a few paces to the rear, still watching the trees behind them. The barrels of the guns follow them from the bunker as th approach.

The huge bunker is sunk into the tree-covered hillside. T three soldiers make their way up the slope and along the wall, stumbling occasionally in the snow, or on the hidde ropes of the camouflage netting. At the rear, a deep trench leads to the entrance: this is overlooked by another loophole in the wall of the Entranc Defence Room. As they struggle down the crude steps into trench, the steel shutter of this loophole GRATES open to watch them. Ebert arrives first at the heavy steel door, and kicks it EBERT (cont’d) Open up, dammit! For a moment the three of them wait in silence and stilln Ebert looking up at the lettering moulded into the concre above the door. It reads ‘FRIEDA’. Sound of bolts SLAMMING back, and the door swings open. Ebert stands aside to let Heydrich hobble through first
Heydrich is barely inside before he is PUSHED roughly aga the wall, a pistol at his throat.

Hey! What the...? And everybody FREEZES. Heydrich is staring back into the face of another German soldier -- a reserve Volksgrenadier. This is MIRUS, an ol man with crazy eyes and a crazy demeanour. An old, livid wound is visible on his forehead -- and he looks ill.
(to Heydrich) Who are you? He rips open Heydrich’s collar, checking his dog-tag. MIRUS (cont’d) Let me hear you speak.
Heydrich. 13th Panzergrenadiers.
Let him go, old man!
(to Baumann) You! Say something. Why are you here?
We were ambushed. Now take it easy!
Ambushed?

It’s a bit late to be asking questions, Private. Put the gun down. Mirus blinks, his eyes slowly losing their crazy gleam. HEYDRICH (cont'd) The gun! Mirus finally backs off. Everybody BREATHES again. Heydri rubs his throat, cursing silently.  11. As if his mind has suddenly changed gear, Mirus looks at other three soldiers as if seeing them for the first time He stokes his old head wound unconsciously.
I’m sorry... The others look at him warily, unsettled by his radical change in temperament. MIRUS (cont‘d) We were warned, you see. About enemy infiltration units.

If you weren’t sure about us you should never have opened the door. Ebert SLAMS and bolts the door behind them. (They’re in a short, T-shaped passage: To their right, a small flight of steps leads down to another steel door; t the left, the Gas Lock which leads deeper into the bunker Mirus shuffles sheepishly for a second, embarrassed at hi behaviour, then gestures for them to follow.
This way. Mirus leads them through the
MIRUS (cont’d) What happened to you, again? then turns right through the gas-proof doors into the

Ambush. Americans. Doors in each wall of the corridor lead to the Generator and the Crew Room. Straight ahead is the door to the Gun Room. Peering around it curiously is a 2nd Volksgrenadier This is NEUMANN; young, almost a boy. Mirus snaps at him:
Keep watching the front! Neumann disappears out of sight as Mirus leads the others right again, into the --  12.

Bunks. Lockers. Pin-ups. Military mottoes painted on the walls. Small stove. Emergency Escape. A Christmas tree -- with an ironic cardboard SWASTIKA on top instead of an angel. The three newcomers slump down onto the bunks near the st A bit of warmth and comfort. The relief spreads across th faces -- but this only accentuates their pain and exhaust Heydrich stretches out his injured leg.
Ahhh!! Shit! Meanwhile, Mirus hovers nervously, occasionally coughing.
How far away did all this happen? The ambush?
Three, four kilometres.
But the front-line is supposed to be thirty-odd kilometres away.
That’s what we thought. One by one, they light up cigarettes.
God knows what the Yanks were doing there. Probably don’t even know themselves. Baumann is studying Mirus’s reaction:
They might be coming this way. Mirus turns pale. He looks at the other two for confirmation.
Will they?
Maybe. They were behind us for a while, back there. All they have to do is follow our tracks in the snow.  13.
(to Mirus) How many men do you have? Mirus nervously strokes the wound on his forehead.
Just one. The three newcomers stiffen, alert. The relaxation drains from their faces, to be replaced once more by tension.
You mean that kid?
Everybody else was sent forward. They even took our supplies.
Christ!
Is it like this all along the line, now? Just Reserves?
I don’t know. I think so. (defensive) There’s not supposed to be any fighting here!
Someone forgot to tell the Yanks.
(to Mirus) You’d better get onto Area Command. Mirus turns to leave, fretting. Ebert calls after him. EBERT (cont’d) What was it you said before, about infiltration units?
Americans in German uniform. Sometimes they --
We know what they are. What about them?
We were just told to be on the lookout for them.  14.

Well, don’t shoot at anyone until you know who it is. There may be others coming, from our unit. Mirus nods and exits. Ebert snorts derisively. EBERT (cont’d) I don’t believe it! Kids and sick crazy old men left in charge.

That’s what it’s come to, alright A moment of brooding silence. Heydrich gets out his first aid kit and sees to his leg. Ebert gets up and smells the coffee pot on the stove. Ersatz! He pulls a sour face, but pours a mug-full anyway passes it around. Baumann continues where they’d left off
So, if the Yanks attack again it’1l be up to us.

They won’t necessarily come after us. They might have other priorities. But he doesn’t sound as if he quite believes it. And it’s clear from their faces that nor do Heydrich and Baumann. Ebert stares for a moment into his coffee mug -- then rai it in a tired, ironic toast: EBERT (cont’d) Well. Happy Christmas! Sudden SHOUT from the Gun Room:
Someone’s coming!
EBERT’S POV - THROUGH BINOCULARS A small group of German soldiers flit cautiously between trees, at the bottom of the slope overlooked by the bunke Three, maybe four of them.
Ours, alright. What's left of them.  15.
Can I see?
Ebert is peering out through the loophole. He passes the binoculars to Baumann, then turns to Neumann at the gun.
What's your name?

Neumann, sir. Ebert looks around: (The room is dim -- lights out becaus the loophole cover is open) 4.7 cm cannon/machine gun; am boxes; door to the Ammunition Room; not much else. In the b.g., Mirus is on the wall-mounted field-telephone LIBBING terse, monosyllabic comments and replies. Heydrich is leaning expectantly in the doorway. Ebert turns back to Neumann and indicates the huge gun;
Are you alright with this? Neumann nods with a hint of defiance;
I used to be on a Flak unit. Ebert is quiet for a moment, looking sadly at this over- confident kid who should be back at home with his family. He gestures at Mirus and continues;
Did he explain to you what's going on? What's his name?
Mirus. Yes, sir.

Alright. Keep the gun trained on the trees. Just in case. Neumann nods. EBERT (cont’d) This isn't like shooting at planes. If you have to fire, use short bursts.  16. Another dismissive, slightly annoyed nod, and Neumann put his eye back to the gunsight. Mirus hangs up the phone. He's even more agitated, now.
They just said to let them know of any developments. That's all!
(ironic) Great! Sound of indistinct SHOUTING from outside.
They're out of the trees. Coming in.

The four soldiers are now dodging between the concrete ta traps, waving towards the bunker. One of them is being helped along by the others. BAUMANN (0.S.) (cont'd) Krupp; Schenke; Franke. Can't see who they're dragging. Is it Kreuzmann?
Call out to them. Baumann opens his mouth to shout through the loophole... GUNFIRE bursts from the distant trees. Baumann and Ebert instinctively duck, grabbing their rifl
Shit! ! Mirus scrambles back to the gun. Pushes Neumann out of th way. Takes over. Baumann works the bolt on his rifle. Aims through the loophole. FIRES towards the trees.

Panic! The four newcomers are yelling incoherently as they scram up the icy slope, under fire from an unseen enemy. SHOTS are coming from the trees. KICKING into the snow around them. PRANGING off the concrete tank-traps. They'r in the open -- sitting ducks! Franke is dragging the injured Kreuzmann. Krupp is pushin them along with one hand and FIRING blindly towards the t with the other. Schenke brings up the rear, laying down a covering fire as he backs up the slope. On their faces is the fear of God. Schenke is HIT. He shouts involuntarily and stumbles; but second later he is up again, still firing. A bullet CLANGS against the side of Franke's helmet. He shouts a string of incoherent CURSES. All this happens in the space of six seconds.
Baumann squeezes off another SHOT. Ebert SHOUTS at Mirus;
What the hell are you waiting for?
I can't see the enemy!

Just fire! The machine gun EXPLODES into action. The NOISE within th confined concrete space is incredible. Baumann FIRES again, finishing his clip. Pulls away from the loophole. Ebert takes his place instantly, firing. Neumann breaks open a new ammo belt for the gun. Heydrich finishes loading shells into a rifle magazine. Tosses it to Baumann. EBERT (cont’d) They're coming around the side! Baumann SLAMS the clip into his rifle.  18.
I’m alright here. Go! Ebert pulls away from the loophole and Baumann smoothly t his place, FIRING immediately. Heydrich catches on straight away. Follows Ebert out of the room.
Ebert races for the rear. Heydrich hobbles behind him.
I'll get the door. They pile into the Gas Lock. Ebert branches off right. Heydrich goes left, around the dog-leg to the main door.
A small, bare, cramped room. Loophole in the outer wall. Ebert is at the loophole in an instant. Checks outside. SHOUTS through to Heydrich:
Clear!

Heydrich pulls open the door just in time for the new arrivals to SPILL inside, almost falling over each other. He SLAMS the door shut behind them. They collapse against the wall and sink to the floor. For few moments they say nothing, catching their breath and gradually realising they're still alive. Franke leans back with his eyes closed, pale and tremblin and hugging his steel helmet to his chest. Lieutenant Krupp wipes his face with a handkerchief -- an looks uneasily around the cramped space, pulling open his collar. The MUFFLED SHOOTING continues in the b.g. Heydrich takes a look at Kreuzmann, who is semi-conscious obviously in the worst condition.
What happened to the others?  19. Schenke struggles back to his feet painfully.
Take a wild guess!
(to Heydrich) Who else is here?
Ebert and Baumann. Schenke starts to CHUCKLE ironically, but it emerges as a breathless cough. He looks at his wounded side -- then suddenly KICKS the wall in a violent, cathartic release o tension.
The machine gun is still BOOMING. The air is thick with cordite smoke. Baumann is trying to shout over the noise. The gun stops momentarily.

enough! Hold fire! Another short BURST, and the gun stops again. Empty shells RATTLE down the collection tube. Sudden, complete silence. Mirus is glued, rigid, to the gunsight of the machine gun Baumann cautiously peeks through the loophole. BAUMANN (cont’d) That might hold them for a while. Krupp enters and takes in the scene. He throws a glance a Baumann, then addresses Mirus.
Are you in charge here? Mirus and Neumann straighten to attention.
Yes, sir. Krupp heads immediately for the loophole, and Baumann ste aside to give him access. He turns for the door, but Krup calls him back:
Baumann!  20. Baumann stops where he is and waits patiently, whilst Kru studies the scene outside. KRUPP (cont’d) (to Mirus) You've been on to Area Command?
Yes sir.
That covering fire was bloody late. Who was on the gun? Mirus hesitates momentarily -- coughing.
I was, sir. Krupp turns away from the loophole and looks Mirus up and down, taking in his Volksgrenadier uniform, and noticing the first time how sick he appears.

Jesus! You look worse than us. Mirus says nothing, waiting for his telling-off. Neumann too is expectant -- but Krupp leaves it hanging in the ai KRUPP (cont’d) What other covering fire is there, apart from this?
There's a machine gun nest across the pass, sir. -- But nobody to man it. Krupp nods to himself.
Alright. I'll talk to Area Command again. In the meantime, if anything moves out there, shoot. Instantly! Mirus SNAPS his heels, relieved.
Yes, sir! He turns back to the gunsight -- whilst Neumann's face betrays a momentary disappointment and irritation that Mi is off the hook. Meanwhile, Krupp half-turns to Baumann.  21.
How long ago did you get here?

Just a few minutes before you did. A pregnant pause. BAUMANN (cont’d) We looked for you. Krupp turns away again without reply. He looks around the smoky room and suddenly seems short o breath. Face close to the loophole for air, he tugs at hi collar claustrophobicaly, and barks an order.
Someone turn on the vents.

Kreuzmann is helped onto one of the bunks by Franke and Schenke, Heydrich following behind with his kit. Having l go of Kreuzmann, Schenke slumps onto the next bunk, looki down again at his bleeding side. He’s still steamed.
Bastards! Behind us all the shitting way. Don't they know when to quit?
Let me see it. Franke tries to look at his wound, but Schenke shrugs him angrily, gesturing at Kreuzmann:
Just get on with pampering him! Heydrich is still settling Kreuzmann.

(calmly) He’s hurt, Schenke. And he lost his friend back there. Schenke isn’t impressed, but drops the subject. Franke ta over the tending of Kreuzmann, and Heydrich hobbles over bunk at the other side of the room. Schenke eases himself back against the wall, taking deep breaths to calm himself and control the pain -- an Iron C 2nd class glinting visibly on his tunic.  22. Then he rests momentarily, eying Heydrich.
How many do you think, out there?
Who knows? Enough, anyway.
I reckon two or three snipers and a machine gun each side of the road. Plus maybe a couple on demolition.
(shaking head) More than that.
If we hadn’t split up, we could’ve fought it out.
(impatient) And got ourselves killed.
It was ten or twelve men at most.
Yes, and God knows how many more coming up from behind.
(surprised) What do you mean? You saw others?
I didn’t see them, no, but --
Then who says? Heydrich shakes his head dismissively, annoyed that he’d allowed himself to be drawn into an argument.
(weary) Don’t start, Schenke. Schenke glances over at Franke momentarily, intrigued -- leans forward eagerly.
We pulled back without bumping into anyone else. How do you think we got out of there!? (a pause) (MORE)

So. Who r@uHENKH ecw’ @i1 these 23. other Yanks? Heydrich remains silent -- and Schenke suddenly becomes a that Baumann is standing in the doorway, listening. Baumann and Schenke glare at each other for a moment -- t Schenke SNIGGERS, shaking his head contemptuously. Baumann stands his ground defiantly.

Krupp wants you up front Schenke takes a small container from his pocket, shakes a pill into his hand, and tosses it into his mouth. Then he gets to his feet and strolls to the door -- pausi just long enough to glare once more into Baumann’s eyes - pointedly and childishly polishing his Iron Cross with hi cuff -- as if to emphasis that Baumann doesn’t have one. And with that, Schenke exits.
(after a moment) Little bastard! Baumann changes the subject.

We’re going to siege conditions. Krupp wants you to organise a rota, three-hour shifts. Heydrich nods, gets up, and departs without further comme The shocked and injured Kreuzmann meanwhile, who has rema semi-conscious throughout, is slowly coming to his senses Still groggy, he struggles to focus on Franke and Baumann
(after a moment) Did ... Engels make it?

(gently) No. He’s momentarily confused -- then anguish creases his fac as if the memories of what had happened suddenly flood ba FRANKE (cont’d) It’s alright. wWe’re safe, now. Baumann watches as tears drip silently from Kreuzmann’s e Uncomfortable, he, too, departs.  24. Left alone with Kreuzmann, Franke struggles to find words comfort. FRANKE (cont’d) I... couldn’t have got to him, Kreuzmann. I’m sorry.

Nobody tried to help him. Not even me. Franke doesn’t know what else to say. Instead, he slumps back and blows out a weary sigh. Kreuzmann composes himself slightly after a few moments. KREUZMANN (cont’d) Where is this place?
(a shrug) Just an anti-tank bunker Kreuzmann shivers momentarily, suddenly chilled. He glanc around the room, as if sensing something...

It’s not safe here. But Franke is no longer listening; he’s studying the fres bullet-dent on the side of his steel helmet introspective as if dwelling on the close-shave. So Kreuzmann turns his attention again to his surrounding his gaze finally settling on the square steel hatch leadi to the bunker’s Emergency Escape shaft...

Darkness, except for the faint diffused moonlight filteri in through the loophole at which Schenke is keeping watch Mirus and Neumann are manning the cannon, while Baumann, Ebert and Heydrich wait expectantly just inside the doorw Krupp, meanwhile, is on the field telephone:

but the situation’s approaching critical. -- No, we don’t know that for sure. -- Yes. -- Yes, alright He puts down the receiver, exasperated, and turns to the group.  25. KRUPP (cont’d) All units are up at the front. No reinforcements available. We’re to hold until relieved.
Hold with what?
I doubt they’1l attack the bunker. They don’t know we’re low on ammo, and this time they don’t have the element of surprise.
They don’t need it if there’s an armoured column heading straight for us. Krupp glares at him, flustered and annoyed. There are clearly still tensions between the two surviving halves o the group.
And where’s this armoured column coming from?
The same place they did! We don't know what's going on at the front line.
Command think it’s either an infiltration unit or an isolated pocket of resistance.
And what do you think about that Baumann? Baumann ignores the mocking tone of Schenke’s voice.
I think there’s a lot more out there than we realise.
Well, that’s your story, anyway.
Leave it, Schenke. You don’t know what you’re talking abou --
Don’t make excuses for me. Not to him!  26. There’s a second of icy tension -- then Ebert picks up wh the conversation left off.
